âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Homomorphic evaluation: \evalâ€‹(c1,c2)=c1âˆ˜c2=\encâ€‹(\pk,m1)âˆ˜\encâ€‹(\pk,m2)=\encâ€‹(\pk,m1âˆ˜m2)\evalsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2\enc\pksubscriptğ‘š1\enc\pksubscriptğ‘š2\enc\pksubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2\eval(c_{1},c_{2})=c_{1}\circ c_{2}=\enc(\pk,m_{1})\circ\enc(\pk,m_{2})=\enc(\pk,m_{1}\circ m_{2}), where âˆ˜\circ refers to an operator, e.g., addition or multiplication.
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Decryption: m1âˆ˜m2â†\decâ€‹(\sk,\encâ€‹(\pk,m1âˆ˜m2))â†subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2\dec\sk\enc\pksubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2m_{1}\circ m_{2}\leftarrow\dec(\sk,\enc(\pk,m_{1}\circ m_{2})). Using \sk\sk\sk, the operational results of m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} and m2subscriptğ‘š2m_{2} can be derived.

Oblivious Transfer (OT). OTÂ [52] is one of the crucial building blocks for MPC. In an OT protocol (involving two parties), a sender holds nğ‘›n different strings si,i=1â€‹â‹¯â€‹n,subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘›s_{i},i=1\cdots n, and a receiver has an index (iâ€‹nâ€‹dğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘‘ind) and wants to learn siâ€‹nâ€‹dsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘‘s_{ind}. At the end of the protocol, the receiver cannot get information about strings rather than siâ€‹nâ€‹dsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘‘s_{ind}, while the sender learns nothing about iâ€‹nâ€‹dğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘‘ind selected by the receiver. For example, a 1-out-of-2 OT protocol only inputs two strings and a 1-bit index.

Garbled Circuits (GC)Â [5]. The protocol is run between two parties called the garbler and evaluator. The garbler generates the GC corresponding to the Boolean circuit to be evaluated securely by associating two random keys per wire representing the bit values 0, 1. The garbler then sends the GC together with the keys for the inputs to the evaluator. The evaluator obliviously obtains the keys for his inputs via OT and evaluates the circuit to obtain the output key. Finally, the evaluator maps the output key to the real output.

-C4 Differential Privacy

Differential Privacy (DP)Â [22] is a data protection approach enabling one to publish statistical information of datasets while keeping individual data private. The security of DP requires that adversaries cannot statistically distinguish the changes between two datasets where an arbitrary data point is different. The most widely used DP mechanism is called (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP defined below, requiring less injection noise than the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP but standing at the same privacy level.

Definition 1 ((Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta) - Differential PrivacyÂ [22]).

Given two real positive numbers (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta) and a randomized algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}: ğ’Ÿnâ†’ğ’´â†’superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›ğ’´\mathcal{D}^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}, the algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} provides (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta) - DP if for all data sets ğƒ,ğƒâ€²âˆˆğ’Ÿnğƒsuperscriptğƒâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›\mathbf{D},\mathbf{D}^{{}^{\prime}}\in\mathcal{D}^{n} differing in only one data sample, and all ğ’®âŠ†ğ’´ğ’®ğ’´\mathcal{S}\subseteq\mathcal{Y}: Pâ€‹râ€‹[ğ’œâ€‹(ğƒ)âˆˆğ’®]â‰¤eâ€‹xâ€‹pâ€‹(Ïµ)â‹…Pâ€‹râ€‹[ğ’œâ€‹(ğƒâ€²)âˆˆğ’®]+Î´.ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿdelimited-[]ğ’œğƒğ’®â‹…ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-Ïµğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿdelimited-[]ğ’œsuperscriptğƒâ€²ğ’®ğ›¿Pr[\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{D})\in\mathcal{S}]\leq exp(\epsilon)\cdot Pr[\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{D}^{{}^{\prime}})\in\mathcal{S}]+\delta.

Note that the Gaussian noise ğ’©âˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,Î”2â€‹Ïƒ2)similar-toğ’©ğ‘0superscriptÎ”2superscriptğœ2\mathcal{N}\sim N(0,\Delta^{2}\sigma^{2}) should be added to the output of the algorithm, where Î”Î”\Delta is L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} sensitivity of ğƒğƒ\mathbf{D} and Ïƒğœ\sigma=2â€‹lnâ¡(1.25/Î´)21.25ğ›¿\sqrt{2\ln(1.25/\delta)}Â [1]. The robustness of post-processing guarantees for any probabilistic/deterministic functions â„±â„±\mathcal{F}, if ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} satisfies (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, so does â„±â€‹(ğ’œ)â„±ğ’œ\mathcal{F(A)}.

-D Complexity Analysis

We use dğ‘‘d to denote the dimension of the model. nğ‘›n, Sğ‘†S and cğ‘c refer to the number of clients, servers and clusters, respectively.
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Computation cost. Each clientâ€™s computation cost can be computed as binary SS with Tiny OT âˆ’- Oâ€‹(d)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘O(d). The serverâ€™s computation cost consists of 4 parts: (1) computing pairwise XOR âˆ’- Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}); (2) bit to arithmetic conversion âˆ’- Oâ€‹(d)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘O(d); (3) multiplication for L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} distance âˆ’- Oâ€‹(n3)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›3O(n^{3}); (4) comparison with Î±ğ›¼\alpha âˆ’- Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}); (5) calculating results of HHF based on the number of clusters cğ‘c âˆ’- Oâ€‹(nâ€‹c)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘O(nc). Thus, the total computation complexity of each server is Oâ€‹(n3)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›3O(n^{3}).
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Communication cost. For a client in MUDGUARD, the communication cost can be divided into 2 parts: (1) sending updates to Sğ‘†S servers with binary SS and Tiny OT âˆ’- Oâ€‹(Sâ€‹d)ğ‘‚ğ‘†ğ‘‘O(Sd); (2) broadcasting hash results of updates to the rest of parties âˆ’- Oâ€‹(n+S)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘†O(n+S). Thus, we have communication complexity âˆ’- Oâ€‹(Sâ€‹d+n)ğ‘‚ğ‘†ğ‘‘ğ‘›O(Sd+n) for each client. The serversâ€™ communication costs include (1) receiving correlated randomness and doubly-authenticated bits for converting a boolean shared matrix to arithmetic one âˆ’- Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}); (2) receiving triples for multiplications âˆ’- Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}); (3) receiving correlated randomness for element-wise comparison âˆ’- Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}); (4) sending shares and a random bit to other servers for reconstruction âˆ’- Oâ€‹(Sâ€‹n2)ğ‘‚ğ‘†superscriptğ‘›2O(Sn^{2}); (5) sending aggregated shares and values of HHF to all clients âˆ’- Oâ€‹(nâ€‹d)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘O(nd). Overall, the communication cost for every server is Oâ€‹(Sâ€‹n2)ğ‘‚ğ‘†superscriptğ‘›2O(Sn^{2}). For detailed experimental results, refer to SectionÂ V-B.

-E Security Analysis

We first define the ideal functionality â„±MUDGUARDsubscriptâ„±MUDGUARD\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{MUDGUARD}} to execute a byzantine-robust privacy-preserving FL, and then show that the proposed protocol Î MUDGUARDsubscriptÎ MUDGUARD\Pi_{\textsf{MUDGUARD}} securely realizes the functionality. Our security is based on the random oracle model where the homomorphic hash function outputs a uniformly random value for a new query and the same value for a previously answered query, hence we prove the UC security in â„±ROsubscriptâ„±RO\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{RO}}-hybrid model. Besides, the security is also based on the existence of a secret sharing protocol where the clients derive shares indistinguishable with randoms which securely realizes â„±SSsubscriptâ„±SS\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}} (a combination of â„±triples,â„±share,â„±reconstsubscriptâ„±triplessubscriptâ„±sharesubscriptâ„±reconst\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{triples}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{share}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{reconst}}Â [27]), and a bit-to-arithmetic conversion protocol that securely realizes â„±B2Asubscriptâ„±B2A\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{B2A}} (noted as â„±PREPsubscriptâ„±PREP\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{PREP}} inÂ [54]).

Upon receiving (Abort)Abort(\textbf{Abort}) from either the adversary or any client, send âŸ‚perpendicular-to\perp to all parties and terminate.

Remark.

According to the ideal functionality, we could capture not only privacy but also soundness against malicious corruption of servers. However, the differential attack is based on the output of each epoch, which is published roundly and could be obtained legally. Hence, the discussion on differential privacy is not included in this security definition. Detailed proof for differential privacy will be given later. Moreover, soundness against malicious corruption of clients is also not captured by the previous definition since such security is protected by the clustering technique, which is not the concern of cryptography.

Definition 2 (Universally Composable security).

A protocol Î Î \Pi UC-realizes ideal functionality â„±â„±\mathcal{F} if for any PPT adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} there exists a PPT simulator ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} such that, for any PPT environment â„°â„°\mathcal{E}, the ensembles ğ–¤ğ–·ğ–¤ğ–¢Î ,ğ’œ,â„°subscriptğ–¤ğ–·ğ–¤ğ–¢Î ğ’œâ„°\mathsf{EXEC}_{\Pi,\mathcal{A},\mathcal{E}} and ğ–¤ğ–·ğ–¤ğ–¢ğ–¨ğ–£ğ–¤ğ– ğ–«â„±,ğ’®,â„°subscriptğ–¤ğ–·ğ–¤ğ–¢subscriptğ–¨ğ–£ğ–¤ğ– ğ–«â„±ğ’®â„°\mathsf{EXEC}_{\mathsf{IDEAL}_{\mathcal{F}},\mathcal{S},\mathcal{E}} are indistinguishable.

Definition 3 (UC security of MUDGUARD).

A protocol Î MUDGUARDsubscriptÎ MUDGUARD\Pi_{\textsf{{MUDGUARD}}} is UC-secure if Î MUDGUARDsubscriptÎ MUDGUARD\Pi_{\textsf{{MUDGUARD}}} UC-realizes â„±â„±\mathcal{F}, against malicious-majority clients and malicious-minority servers, considering arbitrary collusion between malicious parties.

Theorem 3 (UC security of MUDGUARD).

Suppose the existence of a homomorphic hash function in a random oracle model, our protocol is UC-secure in (â„±RO,â„±SS,â„±B2A)subscriptâ„±ROsubscriptâ„±SSsubscriptâ„±B2A(\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{RO}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{B2A}})-hybrid world.

UC framework captures attacks on input and intermediate data. On the contrary, differential privacy prevents the adversary from inferring about private information from outputs or updates, and such information might also be utilized by malicious clients. When false positives clustering exists, or malicious clients pretend to be honest, local updates have a chance to be revealed to the adversary. The following theorem shows that these updates do not leak any individual data due to differential privacy.

Theorem 4.

No adversary in corrupted client set \advcâŠ‚ğ’superscript\advğ‘ğ’\adv^{c}\subset\mathcal{C}, where |\advc|â‰¤nâˆ’1superscript\advğ‘ğ‘›1|\adv^{c}|\leq n-1, can retrieve the individual values of honest clients.

Proof.

Since we apply differential privacyÂ [22], the local updates cannot leak information regarding the inputs. According to Def.Â 1, the added differentially private noise guarantees that the aggregation is indistinguishable whether an individual update participates or not. Therefore, it guarantees the security of individual local updates while aggregation can be calculated. âˆ

-G Proof of Theorem 1

-H Other Experimental Setup and Experimental Results

-H1 Other Experiment Setup

We implement MUDGUARD in C++ and Python. We use MP-SPDZ libraryÂ [33] to implement secure computations and Pytorch frameworkÂ [51] for training. All the experiments are conducted on a cluster of machines with Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2620 v4 @ 2.10GHz and NVIDIA 1080 Ti GPU, with 32GB RAM in a local area network. As for the cryptographic tools, all the parameters are set to a 128-bit security level.
Datasets. We use MNIST and FMNIST datasets for the image classification task.
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet MNISTÂ [39]. It consists of 60,000 training samples and 10,000 testing samples, where each sample is a 28Ã—\times28 gray-scale image of handwritten digital (0-9).
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet FMNISTÂ [61]. It contains article images from Zalando and has the same size as MNIST, where each image is a 28Ã—\times28 gray-scale image associated with a label from 10 classes.
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet CIFAR-10Â [36]. It offers 50,000 training samples and 10,000 test samples, where each is a 32Ã—\times32 color image in a label from 10 different objectives, and there are 6,000 images for each class.
Classifiers. We use LeNet and ResNet-18 to perform training and classification of the datasets.
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet LeNetÂ [38]. Containing 6 layers (including 3 convolution layers, 2 pooling layers, and 1 fully connected layer), LeNet aims to train 44,426 parameters for image classification.
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet ResNet-18Â [32]. It provides 18 layers with 11 million trainable parameters to train color images. We use a light vision of ResNet with approx. 2.07 million parameters and complete the experiments with the CIFAR-10 dataset.

-H2 Other Experimental Results

In FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5, we present the comparison of testing accuracy among baseline, semi-honest and malicious groups under targeted attacks and ASR between the groups under untargeted attacks. In addition, we also give the experimental results by varying proportion of malicious clients (Î¾â‰¥0.5ğœ‰0.5\xi\geq 0.5), #clients nğ‘›n and non-iid degree qğ‘q in TablesÂ VII andÂ VIII. We see that the results are consistent with the analysis in SectionÂ V-A: the untargeted attacks nearly have no impact on the accuracy of the final model (only slightly decreasing the speed of convergence). Since GA may directly upload noise, it can be easily detected from the beginning of the training to the end, resulting in the same convergence as the baseline. For LFA, Krum, Trim, and AA Attacks, MUDGUARD is also difficult to distinguish between semi-honest and malicious clients at the beginning. Thus, the speed of convergence is slightly decreased. The main difference is that: LeNet achieves around 78%percent7878\% in FMNIST, while ResNet-18 provides approx. 56%percent5656\% accuracy in CIFAR-10.

We also provide comparisons with the state-of-the-art Byzantine-robust methods in FigureÂ 6 andÂ 7 on FMNIST and CIFAR-10 respectively. Similar to FigureÂ 3, under the malicious majority of untargeted attacks, the testing accuracies of FLTrust, MUDGUARD, and weights-MUDGUARD are maintained at the same level of the baseline. Under the targeted attacks, FLTrust, MUDGUARD, and weights-MUDGUARD can restrain ASR to about 0%-10%. For more detailed explanations, please refer to SectionÂ V-A.

Impact of Î±ğ›¼\alpha on robustness of MUDGUARD Turning back to SectionÂ IV-B and TheoremÂ 1, the Byzantine-robustness of MUDGUARD relies on whether we can choose a desirable density Î±ğ›¼\alpha. From the experimental results in SectionÂ V-A, we know that EA has a stronger stealthiness than other attacks. Therefore, we use EA as an example in this section to analyze the influence of Î±ğ›¼\alpha on MUDGUARD. FigureÂ 8 shows how the ASR and clustering accuracy varies in semi-honest and malicious groups under EA when we change Î±ğ›¼\alpha. Consistent with TheoremÂ 1, once Î±ğ›¼\alpha is great than 22\sqrt{2}, the malicious and semi-honest clients will cluster together, resulting in MUDGUARD loss of the effectiveness of Byzantine-robustness. A similar situation can be found when Î±ğ›¼\alpha is set as too small (in this case, all clients will be identified as noise.). From the experiment, we found 1 is a best practice for Î±ğ›¼\alpha, so we set it as the default parameter. Nevertheless, MUDGUARD cannot 100% guarantee to exclude EA because EA has a strong stealthiness. We will leave this as future work.

Impact of Î»ğœ†\lambda on Adaptive Attack. FigureÂ 9 shows how the ASR varies in semi-honest and malicious groups when we adapt BA to MUDGUARD, where (F)MNIST, CIFAR-10 and default settings in TableÂ II are used. In MNIST (FigureÂ 9a), the ASR of the semi-honest group remains at a low level (nearly 0%) while that of the malicious group raises from 0.23 to 1 as Î»ğœ†\lambda grows from 0.1 to 0.3. This is so because when the value of Î»ğœ†\lambda is low, the malicious clients using AA more focus on evading filtering (i.e., inducing a drop in clustering accuracy). Even if malicious clients are grouped with semi-honest clients, they cannot produce practical attack effectiveness. When the value of Î»ğœ†\lambda gradually increases, the malicious clients will focus more on attack performance. In this way, MUDGUARD will easily distinguish the malicious from the semi-honest. It thus can resist AA. Note the experimental results with FMNIST and CIFAR-10 (FigureÂ 9b and c) share the same trend with MNIST (FigureÂ 9a).

-I Discussions

-I1 Boosting Accuracy

Intuitively, CIFAR-10 is more difficult to train than (F)MNIST. SignSGDÂ [6] achieves 90% accuracy with centralized learning. The reasons for the accuracy drop in FL are (1) the number of clients: when the number increases, the amount of data allocated to a client becomes smaller, and the local model is more prone to overfitting; (2) Data heterogeneity: a larger degree of non-iid leads to less information being available for the local model to learn, which harms accuracy; (3) Malicious clients: malicious clients taking a part of the training data can be filtered out by MUDGUARD. This is equivalent to discarding that part of the training data. Additional improvements in accuracy could be obtained by using different models, e.g., ViTÂ [21], or by performing hyperparameters grid search for FL, etc.

-I2 Comparison of Overheads with FLAME

Intuitively, systems that use clustering, like FLAMEÂ [49], could experience efficiency problem if left without proper optimization. In our design, MPC impacts three main phases: computation of ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—Œğ–¬ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—Œğ–¬\mathsf{CosM}, L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} distance, and element-wise comparison. The 1st stage is the most computationally expensive. We, therefore, focus on its optimization. After the optimization, the servers avoid using â€œheavy" tools, like HE and Beaverâ€™s multiplication, to calculate cosine so that communication and computational overheads are naturally reduced. Therefore, MUDGUARD has much lighter complexity than FLAME.

Note that FLAME uses a 2-party semi-honest MPC scheme which is very similar to the semi-honest situation in our design (TableÂ V). Our optimized version of MUDGUARD is less computationally and communicationally complex than FLAME. In MUDGUARD, ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—Œğ–¬ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—Œğ–¬\mathsf{CosM} is calculated by doing XOR locally on servers, and the matrix size reduces from the number of clients Ã—\times the number of model updates (nÃ—dğ‘›ğ‘‘n\times d) to nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n after calculation. Then this nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n matrix is used to calculate the pairwise-L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} distance (where only multiplication is involved). In FLAME, directly calculating cosine similarity requires multiplication, division, and the square root of the nÃ—dğ‘›ğ‘‘n\times d matrix, which are relatively intensive, expensive operations in MPC. The fact that FLAMEâ€™s code is not publicly available prevents a code/implementation-based comparison.

We followed state-of-the-art Byzantine-robust FLÂ [15]â€™s default setting on the client number (number = 100). TableÂ V shows overheads (the runtime and communication costs) on the server side are acceptable; in particular, only 0.4s and 16 MB are required with LeNet in the semi-honest case.

-I3 Defending Against Other Attacks

In the experiments, we consider SOTA (un)targeted attacks. We say that interested readers may use other attacks to test MUDGUARD, in which Byzantine-robustness could not be seriously affected. We take the Distributed Backdoor Attack (DBA)Â [62] as an example. DBA decomposes a global trigger into several pieces distributed to local clients. It, however, yields significant changes to some dimensions of updates to maintain the ASR of the backdoor task. Since the cosine distance between malicious and benign updates are distinguishable, MUDGUARD can still work well under DBA. Note another attack, Little Is EnoughÂ [4], have not been considered in this work because it requires attackers to have knowledge of the gradients of semi-honest clients, which violates privacy preservation.

-I4 Advantages of Adjusted Cosine Similarity

As shown in FigureÂ 10, we present an example of the calculation of adjusted cosine similarity. It is clear to see that adjusted cosine similarity is able to capture the magnitudes and directions of updates by transferring updates to adjusted updates. Although m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} does not have too many differences in directions (i.e., m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} will be clustered with h1subscriptâ„1h_{1} and h2subscriptâ„2h_{2}), its differences with h1subscriptâ„1h_{1} and h2subscriptâ„2h_{2} in magnitudes can be easily captured by ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—Œğ–¬ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—Œğ–¬\mathsf{CosM}. Furthermore, due to non-iid, the (h1subscriptâ„1h_{1}, h2subscriptâ„2h_{2}) and (h3subscriptâ„3h_{3}, h4subscriptâ„4h_{4}) will be clustered into two groups if cosine distance is applied. However, by subtracting mean updates, this influence can be reduced.

We also show the experimental results in FigureÂ 11, where FMNIST is used under BA and the number of clients is set to 10 (the first six are benign clients, the rest are malicious clients). The rest of the default settings follow TableÂ II. From FigureÂ 10, we can see that if only cosine distance is calculated, honest updates will be classified as noise due to the influence of non-iid. The adjusted cosine similarity weakens this effect (FigureÂ 10b). Calculating the L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} distance again will make the distinction between the two groups more obvious (FigureÂ 10c).

Furthermore, we provide a comparison when MUDGUARD uses cosine similarity and adjusted cosine similarity for clustering in FigureÂ 12. It is clear to see that the testing accuracy of MUDGUARD with cosine similarity abruptly goes down when the model approaches convergence. On the contrary, this does not happen in MUDGUARD with adjusted cosine similarity. The detailed explanation is given in SectionÂ IV-B.

-I5 Dynamic Attacks

Recall that MUDGUARD can perform well in terms of testing accuracy under the assumption that malicious clients consistently perform one type of attack (e.g., GA) throughout the whole training period. It can also perform well if we allow malicious clients to perform different attacks on the epochs, e.g., GA to the first 10 epochs and then Krum attacks to the remaining epochs. We notice that all the attacks (we consider in this work) except GA may require several epochs of training (as a buffer) to produce attack effects. But these buffer epochs can boost MUDGUARDâ€™s clustering performance. This is so because the clustering ability is enhanced with the increase of training rounds. On the other hand, the TNR and TPR (of the clustering) could be relatively low in these epochs. Some malicious clients can be clustered into a semi-honest group, but this will not seriously affect the accuracy performance of the model.

One may think malicious clients are allowed to perform all the attacks in a single epoch. But so far, it is unknown how to group those attacks together friendly and meanwhile maximize their attack effects. In practice, the attacks may deliver an update in different directions, and further, they may even yield influence on each other. For example, GA could easily destroy the convergence of BA. We say that it is an interesting open problem to consider launching GA, LFA, Krum, Trim, and AA attacks together in an epoch to evaluate the accuracy and ARS.

-I6 Varying Clients Subsampling Rate

We assert that MUDGUARD can perform well under different clientsâ€™ subsampling rates. This benefits from the proposed Model Segmentation that can resist malicious-majority clients. Imagine that in the context of an honest majority (e.g., 40 out of 100 are malicious), if the subsampling rate is set relatively low (e.g., 10%), we eventually have a malicious majority case in one training epoch with a high probability. Our experimental results have demonstrated that MUDGUARD can still achieve Byzantine-robustness under a low subsampling rate.

-I7 Learning Rate and Local Epoch

They are subtle parameters that decide the performance of FL training. A low learning rate can slow down the speed of convergence, and on the other hand, a high rate hinders the modelâ€™s convergence, harming accuracy. As for the local epoch, in the case of iid, if carefully increasing the number of epochs, we can make the model converge fast. But under a large degree of non-iid (e.g., q=0.5), the increase of epoch leads to updates in different directions, making the FedAvg algorithm invalidÂ [43]. In this work, we set these two parameters according to the recommendations given in [43, 6]. Exploring their impacts on training is orthogonal to the main focus of this work.

-I8 Privacy-preserving DBSCAN

This is one of the core parts we used to build MUDGUARD. It can apply to other real-world domains, e.g., anomaly detection and encrypted traffic analytics, where data should be clustered securely. But we note that the current MUDGUARD with optimization may not scale well in these applications. We did the optimization for the sake of efficiency by using SignSGD and binary secret sharing, which cannot support precise floating-point arithmetic.

-I9 Test Datasets

We notice that the EA is not applicable for FMINST since the research workÂ [58] did not provide a backdoor dataset. We leave this as an open problem. Based on the performance of MUDGUARD on MNIST and CIFAR-10, we claim that even in FMNIST, the ASR of EA stays low, which is consistent with our main conclusion.

In the experiments, we conduct three image datasets (MNIST, FMNIST, and CIFAR-10). We claim that MUDGUARD can be further used to capture the Byzantine-robust and privacy-preserving features of the models trained on text and speech datasets, where the text dataset for the next-word prediction task can require Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs). To train these datasets, we can also use weights or gradients to update the models (in the context of FL). If the models or datasets are poisoned (by malicious clients), malicious updates have differences in updates directions from benign ones. Then we can use MUDGUARD to protect benign clients. We could use other types of datasets during training, but this will not affect our conclusions on Byzantine robustness and privacy preservation.

-I10 Limitations

Using weights as updates. To provide cost-effective secure computations, the proposed MUDGUARD only implements the update method by SignSGD. If we use weights as updates, the secret shares sent to the servers will be in floating-point format. In this case, we will have to downgrade the design to the unoptimized MUDGUARD in TableÂ V, which could cause a considerable amount of both communication costs and runtime. An interesting future work could be to propose a more lightweight (than the current design) and secure MPC framework for MUDGUARD.

Performance under EA. Although MUDGUARD does achieve good performance in terms of accuracy and (to some extent) efficiency, under the EA, MUDGUARDâ€™s ASR cannot be eventually reduced to nearly 0%. In future work, we will improve the TNR and TPR of the clustering algorithm so as to recognize subtle differences between malicious and semi-honest clients.
